articles.headline: Microsoft Profits Are Hurt by Big Expenses
articles.snippet: The company’s profits rose for the quarter based on strong PC sales in developing markets and rising demand from corporate customers.
articles.abstract: The company’s profits rose for the quarter based on strong PC sales in developing markets and rising demand from corporate customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Thursday reported mixed financial results that drove the company’s stock down almost 5 percent in after-hours trading. In a rare shortfall, the company just missed the forecasts of Wall Street analysts, which had been 47 cents a share according to First Call, the financial research service.

articles.headline: A Cast of 300 Advises Obama on Foreign Policy
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s huge foreign policy team is on the spot as the senator plans his overseas trip.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s huge foreign policy team is on the spot as the senator plans his overseas trip.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Every day around 8 a.m., foreign policy aides at Senator Barack Obama’s Chicago campaign headquarters send him two e-mails: a briefing on major world developments over the previous 24 hours and a set of questions, accompanied by suggested answers, that the candidate is likely to be asked about international relations during the day.

articles.headline: Anti-Energy Speculation Bill Stirs Fear
articles.snippet: Financial industry executives say that a Congressional effort to rewrite the rules for the nation’s energy markets could unsettle already nervous markets and push more energy trading abroad.
articles.abstract: Financial industry executives say that a Congressional effort to rewrite the rules for the nation’s energy markets could unsettle already nervous markets and push more energy trading abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: Financial industry executives are mustering on Capitol Hill to head off a Congressional effort to rewrite the rules for the nation’s energy markets, saying it could unsettle already nervous markets and push more energy trading abroad, beyond the reach of domestic regulators.

articles.headline: Chief Struggles to Revive Merrill Lynch
articles.snippet: During the past 12 months, Merrill, known for its “Thundering Herd” of stockbrokers, has lost about $19.2 billion, which works out to about $52 million a day.
articles.abstract: During the past 12 months, Merrill, known for its “Thundering Herd” of stockbrokers, has lost about $19.2 billion, which works out to about $52 million a day.
articles.lead_paragraph: John A. Thain never said that turning around Merrill Lynch would be easy. “We have not seen the bottom,” he declared in December, when he took the reins of the troubled Wall Street giant.

articles.headline: Got a Fix? Please, Call the Fed
articles.snippet: In the current downward spiral, every institution wants more liquidity and less leverage.
articles.abstract: In the current downward spiral, every institution wants more liquidity and less leverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERGEN, Norway  If only Americans were more like Norwegians.

articles.headline: Boom Times Take Root in Dubai
articles.snippet: The centerpiece of Dubai’s financial hub seems equal to the thrusting ambitions of the foreign investment bankers rushing to set up shop.
articles.abstract: The centerpiece of Dubai’s financial hub seems equal to the thrusting ambitions of the foreign investment bankers rushing to set up shop.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Bathed in the glow of the skyline’s glitter, the centerpiece of Dubai’s financial hub seems equal to the thrusting ambitions of the foreign investment bankers rushing to set up shop here.

articles.headline: Electrical Risks at Iraq Bases Are Worse Than Said
articles.snippet: Shoddy work by private contractors is causing more deaths and injuries on U.S. military bases in Iraq than previously acknowledged, according to documents.
articles.abstract: Shoddy work by private contractors is causing more deaths and injuries on U.S. military bases in Iraq than previously acknowledged, according to documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Shoddy electrical work by private contractors on United States military bases in Iraq is widespread and dangerous, causing more deaths and injuries from fires and shocks than the Pentagon has acknowledged, according to internal Army documents.

articles.headline: Google Earnings Are Below Forecasts, and Shares Fall
articles.snippet: The search giant gave an uncharacteristic disappointment to investors on Thursday, failing to meet at least some of Wall Street’s expectations for its second-quarter performance.
articles.abstract: The search giant gave an uncharacteristic disappointment to investors on Thursday, failing to meet at least some of Wall Street’s expectations for its second-quarter performance.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO Google, the search giant, gave an uncharacteristic disappointment to investors on Thursday, failing to meet at least some of Wall Street’s expectations for its second-quarter performance.

articles.headline: I.B.M. Income Rose 22%, Beating Forecasts
articles.snippet: I.B.M. reported a higher quarterly profit, beating expectations and buoyed by higher sales in the economically troubled United States and abroad because of growth in services, hardware and software.
articles.abstract: I.B.M. reported a higher quarterly profit, beating expectations and buoyed by higher sales in the economically troubled United States and abroad because of growth in services, hardware and software.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  I.B.M. reported Thursday that its net income rose 22 percent in the second quarter to $2.77 billion, or $1.98 cents a share, from the quarter a year-ago quarter.

articles.headline: As Price of Grain Rises, Catfish Farms Dry Up
articles.snippet: Unable to cope with feed costs, southern catfish farmers are draining their ponds and wondering what comes next.
articles.abstract: Unable to cope with feed costs, southern catfish farmers are draining their ponds and wondering what comes next.
articles.lead_paragraph: LELAND, Miss.  Catfish farmers across the South, unable to cope with the soaring cost of corn and soybean feed, are draining their ponds.

articles.headline: New Offshore Bank Limits for U.S. Clients, UBS Says
articles.snippet: Faced with a federal investigation into its private banking practices, the Swiss banking giant said that it would stop offering offshore banking services to clients in the United States.
articles.abstract: Faced with a federal investigation into its private banking practices, the Swiss banking giant said that it would stop offering offshore banking services to clients in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Faced with a federal investigation into its private banking practices, the Swiss banking giant UBS said on Thursday that it would stop offering offshore banking services to clients in the United States.

articles.headline: In Surprise, 2 Tech Titans Disappoint
articles.snippet: Google and Microsoft issued quarterly results on Thursday that disappointed investors.
articles.abstract: Google and Microsoft issued quarterly results on Thursday that disappointed investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Like two straight-A students who uncharacteristically fail an exam, the technology titans Google and Microsoft issued quarterly results on Thursday that disappointed investors.

articles.headline: Talks Signal Mideast Shift
articles.snippet: The United States, Israel and some of their European allies have begun to recognize that trying to defeat their enemies in the region by isolating them has failed.
articles.abstract: The United States, Israel and some of their European allies have begun to recognize that trying to defeat their enemies in the region by isolating them has failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  After years of escalating tensions and bloodshed, the talk in the Middle East is suddenly about talking. The shift is still relatively subtle, but hints of a new approach in the waning months of the Bush administration are fueling hopes of at least short-term stability for the first time since the invasion of Iraq in 2003.
